result_equations.equation: BE = (Z m_H + N m_n - M_nucleus) c^2

explanation: Nuclear binding energy is the energy required to completely separate a nucleus into its constituent protons and neutrons. It represents the mass defect converted to energy when nucleons bind together. The binding energy per nucleon peaks around iron-56, explaining why fusion releases energy for light nuclei and fission for heavy nuclei.
assumptions: The nucleus can be separated into individual protons and neutrons.
The mass of separated nucleons is greater than the bound nucleus mass.
Electron binding energies are negligible compared to nuclear binding energy.

derivation.description: Calculate the total mass of separated nucleons (protons and neutrons).
Find the mass defect as the difference between separated and bound masses.
Apply Einstein's mass-energy relation to convert mass defect to binding energy.
Express binding energy in terms of constituent masses and nuclear mass.
